(16/x) https://t.co/yCtSdGwvP4

1437470546594189313.text: Border agents have to deport most migrants without any consideration and apply a vague humanitarian parole standard that's almost impossible to meet. 1437470541699371008.text: Border patrol told me heartbreaking stories about migrants losing their lives and how their law enforcement work becomes difficult search and rescue missions. 1437470532761382913.text: By eliminating any way to even apply for asylum, the U.S. government is enabling human traffickers to control the process or leaving the strong and fit to their own efforts. Left behind are women, children, elderly, and people with disabilities. (13/x)

1437470531637235715.text: We are violating laws that require us to review migrants for a legitimate fear of persecution in their home countries. Asylum is a legal process. It should be a transparent and fair system. In its place are smugglers and injustice. (12/x)

1437470527786917888.text: She had family to welcome her to the U.S. as did all the other migrants that I spoke with. Wearing masks and waiting their turn, everyone had one question: how do I apply for asylum with the U.S. government? I was a member of Congress, and the answer was grim. (11/x) https://t.co/djmXaR52uP

1437470518131654657.text: One woman came to TX from Ecuador. She was held in detention for days, flown overnight to CA for “processing,” then deposited at the shelter. I held her exhausted daughter, as she told me crying about fleeing an abusive husband. (Thanks @AlOtroLado_Org for translating). (10/x) https://t.co/w2Rdm2HrRK

1437470508975460354.text: I visited Embajadores de Jesús in Tijuana, run by a compassionate pastor who tries to shelter everyone. I saw hundreds of people who have no home and no next step, peacefully and patiently sharing one room. No privacy. No personal belongings. (9/x) https://t.co/KDv8Mtx0zD

1437470500037423104.text: I visited Tijuana and saw the circumstances facing migrants. In the Chaparral camp, gangs control migrants’ lives, often extorting or victimizing them. The violence makes it unsafe for advocates to visit, and I viewed at a distance. (8/x) https://t.co/Hm0AZVlg9u

1437470494551281666.text: The response was silence. Here is the truth: There is no process. A person fleeing violence cannot go to our border and apply for asylum. If you walk up to the border without a visa or U.S. residence, you are ignored. How can migrants get in line if there is no line? (7/x)

1437470490600243205.text: A common point raised about our immigration policy is that those seeking to build a life in the U.S. should “wait in line.” So I asked U.S. Customs and Border Patrol to show me the line. Where would a refugee go? How does screening occur? How long is the wait? (6/x) https://t.co/oGCi4QtT9b

1437470484338151434.text: However, secure borders are not sealed borders. A regular and orderly process for entry—for everything from goods to asylees—is required by U.S. and international laws. One-third of the people I represent are foreign born, and they are neighbors and co-workers. (5/x)

1437470483230781443.text: Border patrol told me that our border is the most secure in its history. Federal data show that the top country of origin for new immigrants is China. Visa overstays now outnumber unlawful border crossings as the main source of unauthorized immigration to the U.S. (4/x)

1437470476805148675.text: At the busiest port of entry, San Ysidro, I saw new screening technology, including biometric and vehicle scanning tools. I crossed into the U.S., seeing for myself how agents use technology, experience, and training to identify unlawful activity. (I was admitted!) (3/x) https://t.co/QwssUVfvX7

1437470468512968706.text: Borders are a necessary part of defining a nation-state. Each country sets border policy on the people and goods that enter and exit, and does so in the context of its neighbors, global affairs, and values. That policy should be lawful and fair. (2/x)

1435717159255040002.text: We're demanding an investment in child care that 1) extends through elementary school, 2) caps costs at 7% of income, 3) avoids unnecessary bureaucracy by administering aid through providers, 4) doesn't bog families down in paperwork, and 5) rebuilds the child care industry.

1435717157975822337.text: We all have an interest in our economy’s future. That means we all have an interest in child care. 1435717156885307393.text: The child care crisis is a crisis of productivity. It's economic quicksand that's miring multiple generations: older folks who provide unpaid child care to grandchildren, parents who exit the workforce, and kids who fall behind because their families can't afford quality care.

1435717155165667328.text: These realities are a big problem for our economy. Businesses can't recruit because child care eats up nearly all entry-level pay. Women are stalled out in parity in achieving leadership positions. Jobs during non-traditional hours are dominated by men.

1435717154041597952.text:
Facts:
1⃣ In most states, child care costs more than in-state college tuition.
2⃣ Child care costs have risen 1000% in recent years—faster than housing and health care.
3⃣ Women got 12% of new jobs last month. At this rate, it’ll take 9 years to return to pre-pandemic employment.

1435717152753872899.text: If you want a strong and growing economy, you should care about child care. 1367874693299122181.text: However, in my last term, House Republicans offered Motions to Recommit in bad faith, to force “gotcha” votes. This year, House rules were changed so that MTRs send bills back to the committees they originate from—delaying votes or killing bills entirely.

1367874692380581893.text: The minority party can offer a Motion to Recommit just before we vote on final passage of a bill. If the MTR is adopted, the text of the bill is revised. Historically, MTRs were offered by Members “friendly” to the bill, as a way to correct errors in the text.

1367874691432611846.text: When I ran for Congress, I made a promise to be transparent about the major decisions I make as Representative for California’s 45th District. So, I’d like to explain “Motions to Recommit” (MTRs) and my recent decision to uniformly vote NO on all of them. [THREAD]

1360411455737131009.text: We just wrapped up our @OversightDems meeting considering COVID disaster relief legislation. Want the inside look? Check out my 🧵🧵on today’s mark-up. https://t.co/ODYatbei5p https://t.co/H6N5mduijN

1360409780460822531.text:
34/34 After 9 hours, the mark-up is finally over! 🙏

We approved our parts of the COVID relief bill by a vote of 23-18 (other committees are in charge of looking at other aspects of COVID relief). Next: votes by the full House.

Thank you to everyone who followed along.

1360381050032066562.text: 33/x I did speak up earlier in this meeting to emphasize how desperately and urgently families need help. Watch 👇👇 https://t.co/sUGh1YDzJk

1360380747714940932.text: 32/x We have now passed 8 hours in this mark up, and I have a little bit of a confession... This is probably the fewest average words per hour that I have ever uttered. It’s been nothing but “yes” or “no,” and we all know that is just not like me.

1360378548536504324.text: 31/x Rep. Comer, who is the Ranking Member of the Committee (highest ranking Republican), is talking about the World Health Organization and how it is responsible for COVID. Attacking international public health efforts is not how to solve a global pandemic.

1360375951381590021.text:
My message during today's @OversightDems meeting:

Americans need help. It doesn’t matter if they’re conservative or liberal. It doesn’t matter if they live in a big city, a suburb, or a small rural town. They are all struggling—and will continue to struggle—unless we act now. https://t.co/Bdpz6du12N

1360373099737190407.text: 30/x One bright side of a long and “robust” mark-up: hearing from new voices, like Byron Donalds and Yvette Harrell. Junior members question last and rarely address the full House, so a mark-up is a real chance to hear their perspectives. I may not agree, but I’m listening. 👂

1360370788516257795.text: 29/x Rep. Comer just lauded his “colleague from Florida who ran to fight for taxpayers of Florida.” He was referring to Rep. Nancy Mace, who represents South Carolina. It's been a long day for everyone. 😬

1360365984247210006.text: 28/x Rep. Nancy Mace (R-SC) used her time to talk about how she serves on 3 committees in Congress and that she has noticed that Democrats and Republicans are not voting together.

1360360982288101382.text: 27/x As is sadly typical, the mark-up has devolved into both sides grumbling that this mark-up is taking too long—and blaming each other for that.

1360360981235335168.text: 26/x Admittedly, a couple amendments (of the 40!) were on topic. For example, we debated whether smaller cities should receive funds directly from the U.S. Treasury via a not yet established system, or should receive funds via distributions to each state, as prior bills did.

1360359595516981249.text: 25/x So far, we have had amendments filed on a range of favorite hot button Republican issues: Keystone XL, Paris Climate Accord, mail-in ballots, abortion, fracking, immigration, census data, etc. None of these are relevant to state and local government funding or the pandemic.

1360359593931493376.text: 24/x We are nearing the 7th hour of this mark-up. Still, many of the amendments being offered are unrelated to the main point of the legislation: funding for state and local governments.

1360338242168475649.text: @OtterFi You can find a list of members here: https://t.co/yeFiCy7ZFF

1360333172337119232.text: 23/x Chairs particularly need a lot of stamina to run a hearing—they must remain in place and preside, or else ask someone to chair temporarily. I’ve never gotten to do it but think it looks like fun. Probably less fun remotely when the actual gavel stays in the hearing room...

1360333170793615361.text: 22/x We are taking a 5 minute recess. This is recess in the same sense as in school. It’s a chance to take a break.

1360333169858285569.text:
21/x I carry 3 cell phones and an iPad and try to have at least two of the devices fully charged at the start of the morning for exactly this reason.

I challenge tech innovators to make a battery that can hold up to the partisanship of Congress!

1360333168918753281.text: 20/x As this mark-up goes on, everybody on a device is plugging in. I started fully charged, plugged in a few hours ago, but video takes so much battery that I’m down to 3%!

1360331898594025473.text: 19/x “En bloc” is when we vote on several amendments together as a package. It's most common when amendments are similar in nature or less controversial. For example, this morning, several amendments tried to limit how states and localities could spend the proposed COVID relief.

1360331897369362432.text: 18/x Republicans have requested recorded votes for all their amendments from the 3 hours of mark-up so far. Committee rules say we can roll these to a fixed time. Several amendments were taken together “en bloc.” What is “en bloc?”

1360331895972663296.text: 17/x Any member can then request a recorded vote. What is a “recorded vote?” It's where the clerk of the Committee calls each member by name and we respond either “yes/aye” or “no/nay.”

1360331894718492672.text: 16/x We paused considering amendments to switch to voting. This is actually the second vote on each amendment. Right after debate, we take a “voice” vote (everyone who agrees says “yes”). The Chair then rules, normally for the party with more members. In this case, the Democrats.

1360313923128283137.text: 15/x Second observation: “Go on mute” is my new phrase for when my kids need to be quiet. I’ve been saying “turn down your volume knob,” but sometimes I really mean “silent!”

1360313921844830208.text: 14/x Chair @RepMaloney again reminds members to “go on mute” because of background noise. Two observations here: (1) this problem isn't limited to virtual hearings. People often discuss amendments among themselves in-person. This can be productive but can also become distracting.

1360310884162183168.text: 13/x Will it go 24 hours? Probably not. Some amendments may not be raised. My best guess is 10 hours. This kind of uncertainty is why being a scheduler is the hardest job on the Hill. And note: you can tune in at home (but don’t hold that against me...) https://t.co/SCKIiJNv3V

1360310881939116032.text: 12/x The second factor is how much debate occurs. After the amendment’s author speaks, a member from the other party is recognized for up to 5 minutes, and then it alternates back and forth between members, for 5 minutes each. Then also add openings and votes. See whiteboard ⬇️ https://t.co/rnR0NiUl4k

1360310878059433987.text: 11/x Why does mark-up take hours? The first factor is the number of amendments. The more proposed changes, the longer the process takes. Each person who puts forth an amendment is given 5 minutes to explain their amendment. Today, we expect about 40 amendments.

1360300312699965444.text: 10/x Amendments must be "germane," i.e. fall under the committee's jurisdiction to amend the bill. An amendment offered today to expand paid leave for Capitol Police isn't germane. While we have to vote no, I hope my colleagues overseeing the Capitol Police consider this measure.

1360293920777793536.text: 9/x Rep. Grothman is making an amendment that would say something the bill already says. Regardless of one’s beliefs, this is just wasting time. It doesn't improve the bill. Our communities have waited and waited for help; now they have to wait through these redundant amendments.

1360286752640954368.text: 8/x One GOP mayor wrote to me: "communities like mine are not asking for a 'bail-out.' Local governments do not expect the federal government to make up for every loss of... revenue. Instead, we seek an additional lifeline... to put off and ultimately avoid last resort options."

1360286751818805248.text: 7/x I've heard from nearly every city in my district, all but one of which has a Republican mayor and Republican majority city council, that they strongly support local funding.

1360285734133850117.text: 6/x Chair @RepMaloney's opening includes letters from mayors in Republican districts, including Bob Gibbs' and Jim Jordan's, asking for help. Example of non-responsive Congressional speechifying: top Republican says sending resources to state and local governments is “wasteful.”

1360283635018911755.text:
5/x Great question from comments: What is a mark up?

Answer: When a bill is introduced, it's given a number and referred to relevant committees. We'll get feedback from stakeholders. Sometimes we'll have hearings on the bills. Then, we debate and amend (or "mark up") the bill.

1360279591416332288.text:
4/x Does wearing glasses help you do good oversight? Maybe. Proud to be part of the club. 🤓

(PS This is my favorite picture of Jim Jordan ever taken.) https://t.co/9WKzcYhaXd

1360277719615868932.text: 3/x That isn’t to say Congress is ready to go full virtual Senate like in Star Wars, although a girl can dream. We just had staff tell a member they weren't on video. “I don’t know what to do. I see a button ‘start my video.’ Do you think I should hit that to start my video?” 🤦‍♀️

1360276915257397248.text: 2/x The hearing is virtual (we use WebEx). It was to start at 12pmEST, and I logged on 3 entire minutes early, seeking extra credit for good attendance. Virtual hearings save time because we don't have to wait 30 or more minutes for members to physically get to the hearing room.

Thanksgiving reminds us to take a pause from the hustle and bustle of our daily lives and appreciate what make our lives special. In this spirit, I wanted a share a few of the things I am thankful for. (THREAD)

Feel free to share some of what you’re grateful for in the replies!

1199408486054010880.text: It’s time we put consumer good before corporate greed. Read my op-ed >> https://t.co/cewJGkUds0

1199408484233682944.text: We have to ask ourselves: who benefits from a system in which half of cancer patients have to deplete their lives’ savings to save their lives? https://t.co/aVXSEcbGoe

1199134476938489856.text:
It’s time for the partisan bickering to stop. Ending violence against women isn’t a Republican issue or a Democratic issue.
 
On Int’l Day to End Violence Against Women, I ask my Senate colleagues to tell women everywhere that they’re still committed to this fight and pass #VAWA.

1199064113051262976.text:
Fighting cancer shouldn't have to put you at war with Big Pharma. Orange County patients saw their costs skyrocket—as high as 400 percent—for the exact same chemo.

Read my latest on how we can put a stop to this corporate abuse >> https://t.co/w4t7OjbhQC

1199044541157916672.text: @KerrieFinch I couldn’t agree more—it’s past time that Congress take action on gun violence. That’s why I proudly co-sponsored and voted for legislation to require universal background checks and to close the Charleston loophole. They passed the House and sit in the Senate.

1197909106067148800.text: I met with healthcare providers in Orange County to hear about their concerns and talk about what we can do at the federal level to be good partners. 1197909096231579648.text: This week, I joined House colleagues in passing legislation that would protect healthcare workers from workplace violence. Healthcare and social service workers are *four times more likely* to suffer serious workplace injuries than workers in other sectors.

1197591023356194816.text: Wells Fargo has said that refunding these charges is “the right thing to do for our customers.” While I appreciate that sentiment, I’ve also written to federal bank watchdogs to make sure the Bank keeps its word. https://t.co/VrymfSfHb3

1197586274644844549.text: New @WellsFargo CEO Charles Scharf has said that he plans to address the Bank's years of consumer abuses and make things right by Wells customers. 1197280229066264576.text: Today, I introduced legislation with @RepDMP & @RepJoeCourtney to require that @usedgov study campus mental health policies and then work to ensure that they are compliant with federal standards. This will help students with mental health concerns finish their degrees. (5/5)

1197280074556477444.text:
Why? Not only do schools force students to leave, but they also make it incredibly difficult to return to campus.

This is the reality for far too many students. I’ve come up with a solution: the Student Mental Health Rights Act. (4/5)

1197280073717633032.text:
You don’t want to take time off—and in fact mental health professionals would recommend that sticking to your routine and being surrounded by your friends is best—but you don’t have a choice. You leave school for a semester.

But you never return to finish your degree. (3/5)

1197280072962658306.text:
Imagine you’re a college student feeling depressed and alone. You don't know where to turn. Finally, you decide to reach out to your school administration for help.

Rather than being connected with school resources, you're told you need to take a leave of absence. (2/5)

1197280072195031042.text:
Rates of depression and anxiety are skyrocketing on college campuses. Some studies have even estimated that the rate of students with depression has doubled in the last ten years.

Let’s talk about this. (THREAD)

Not on my watch.

1183072125785120768.text:
And did Big Pharma use the tax cuts they received in the Trump tax law for research and development? Of course not.

These companies have made $73 billion in buybacks from the Trump tax law, far more than some have spent on research and development. (5/6) https://t.co/7VBpFFJKUx

1183072124694618112.text:
From 2006-2015, Big Pharma spent $465 billion on research and development.

In that same time period, drug companies spent $516 billion to buy back their own stock from shareholders. These buybacks mostly enrich the already wealthy—like CEOs. (4/6)

1183072123767668736.text: Big Pharma likes to say they “need” money from price hikes to research new cures. This work is important, but it’s not the full story. (3/6)

1183072122773659648.text:
My legislation, the Freedom from Price Gouging Act, requires pharmaceutical companies to pay the government back for unnecessary price hikes on drugs covered under Medicare Part B. 

If the price increase is more than inflation, taxpayers shouldn’t foot the bill. (2/6)

1183072120877789184.text: When I was elected, I promised I would fight to drive down the cost of prescription drugs. That’s why I introduced legislation this week taking action against Big Pharma: because we shouldn’t let CEOs line their pockets while older Americans can’t afford their meds. (THREAD)

1182048858299338752.text:

The neighboring OPO serving San Diego recovered 65% more donor organs. (3/7)

1182048857322135552.text:

Yes, we let a bunch of regional monopolies police themselves. What could go wrong? (2/7)

1182048856407789568.text:
Let's talk about organ procurement organizations (OPOs), which are responsible for evaluating and securing organs from those who have decided to donate. The U.S. has 58 OPOs, each one being a regional monopoly.

1167470686073307137.text: Finally, I learned that I have more to learn. I’ll continue to engage these organizations, try to see more facilities, ask more questions, and push for better solutions. Everyone I encountered at the border deserves nothing less than Congress’ full attention on this. (18/18)

1167470684957626368.text: Longer ICE detention and fuller facilities increase the profits of these corporations but may hurt the public. That makes good oversight all the more important. (17/ )

1167470683909054465.text: Fifth, the Otay Mesa Detention Center is run by a for-profit contractor. As a Congressmember, I have a duty to make sure tax dollars are being spent appropriately. Detention should be used to increase public safety, not line the pockets of corporations. (16/ )

1167470682860478467.text: One detainee I spoke to was a single mom working a good job as an office manager in OC for 10 years. She was paying taxes and caring for her kids. Now that she’s detained, she has two kids who are homeless in OC. And taxpayers are paying to surround her with security. (15/ )

1167470681681874945.text:
Criteria for parole release are inconsistent across ICE detention centers, and judges are not regularly involved in this process.

Fourth, many ICE detentions seem to run counter to public safety and good sense. (14/ )

1167470680557768704.text: Part of the reason for long detentions is that ICE decisions on parole are made by one person at each facility—something that surprised me as this is a hugely impactful decision. (13/ )

1167470679500840961.text: Third, ICE detention is often very long. Some detainees are in prison for over a year, which can cause a backlog of people in Border Patrol custody—and those facilities are not designed to house people for more than a day or two at most. (12/ )

1167470678083170304.text: As an aside, Border Patrol agents find it challenging to keep kids in custody. They have compassion: one agent took time away from his family on Christmas to dress up as Santa for the kids at that facility. I met a 2-year old and 4-year old with their mom in a cell. (11/ )

1167470677080735744.text: Kids in CBP get screened with 24 hours by agents with EMT training, but these agents are burning out working long shifts with constant medical work. EMT training is not aimed at detecting illness or assessing chronic conditions; it is trauma training. (10/ )

1167470676027957248.text: Second, Border Patrol needs medical personnel and additional medical training. Adults in CBP custody aren’t getting screened by medical professionals at all, and when they get sick, sometimes entire facilities have to be shut down and decontaminated. (9/ )

1167470674853498880.text: First, better technology will help secure the border. When I asked a border patrol agent if improved technology would help him do his job, he gave a clear yes. And he offered examples and illustrations from his two decades of work. (8/ )

1167470673893060608.text: Below are 6 takeaways I had on how Congress can and should act on to improve the situation at the border: (7/ )

1167470672630566913.text: The openness and respect from the people on the ground, particularly the career Border Patrol agents, seems inconsistent with the apparent move by DHS leadership to deny congressional staff access to facilities. (6/ ) https://t.co/fSdJmmnOe2

1167470671506464769.text: I’m a big believer in accountability, and ICE employees and CBP officers seemed to support the oversight I was conducting. They spoke candidly with me, asked what else I would like to see, and allowed me to speak directly with detainees. (5/ )

1167470670453755905.text: I personally spoke with immigration advocates, social workers, medical professionals, law enforcement officials, and detainees, including families and children. I am taking what I saw and learned firsthand to my constituents in CA and my colleagues in DC  (4/ )

1167470669426069504.text: What is happening in CA is different than in TX or AZ. These differences reflect geography, history, culture, resources, and other factors. My first observation to share: the “southern border” is not a monolithic static  thing and our leaders need to see that. (3/ )

1167470668402704384.text: I visited 3 facilities: the non-profit San Diego Rapid Response Network Migrant Shelter, the Otay Mesa ICE Detention Center, and the Chula Vista Border Patrol (CBP) Station. They interact with immigrants at different stages and were very different from each other.  (2/ )

1167470664581701632.text: Many of you asked for more detail about my trip to the border this week, so I wanted to take time to share my thoughts. (long but important thread)

1138454275078676480.text: If you agree that mental health should be covered like any other type of healthcare, I hope you’ll join @DonaldNorcross and @RepGusBilirakis in supporting H.R. 3165 and getting this bipartisan bill across the finish line.

1138453996732080129.text:
H.R. 3165 has 3 main parts:
✅ plans & insurers must conduct in-depth reviews for compliance with law
✅ gov’t officials directed to request these reviews if there are patient complaints
✅ 50 plans & insurers selected at random for annual compliance investigation

1138453995742277632.text: However, more than a decade later, we’re seeing that health plans and insurers are still violating the law with plans that do not provide equal coverage for mental and medical care. That’s not right, so I introduced a bill to improve enforcement of the existing law.

1138453995029180420.text: It used to be that health plans and insurers could restrict coverage for mental health more than other medical care, so Congress passed the Mental Health Parity and Addiction Equity Act in 2008 to right this wrong.

1138453994039328768.text: Yesterday, I introduced H.R. 3165, the Mental Health Parity Compliance Act, a bipartisan bill to enforce requirements that health plans and insurers treat mental health services the same as any other type of medical care. (THREAD)

1100187654547800064.text: In 2016, the Charleston loophole meant that 4,170 guns were sold to people with criminal records, mental illnesses, or other circumstances which should have prevented them from being able to buy a gun—because FBI background checks weren’t completed in a three day window.

1100187653817987072.text: In 2015, the Charleston loophole in our gun safety laws allowed a self-proclaimed white supremacist to buy a gun that he then used to kill 9 black parishioners at a Bible study—despite a record of illegal drug possession that should have disqualified his purchase.
